BE11:13am

On YouTube, WB21 has posted slickly created videos of an hitherto unheard of event in Frankfurt called “Banker Award 2018”, which he apparently won. On Twitter, where he is also verified and has over 210,000 followers, he posted a picture of his acceptance speech: “A banking tycoon explains the world [sic] how he build his empire”.

According to the SEC, there is no banking empire. Mr Gastauer has touted WB21 as a high-flying start-up with millions of customers and a novel, but only vaguely described, technology that allowed it to make international money transfers more quickly and cheaply than the old, establishment banks.

“In reality, WB21 Group was not a registered bank, and Gastauer’s ‘solution’ was actually a circumvention of banking regulations designed to disguise his clients’ [ . . .] identities,” the SEC said in a civil lawsuit filed in Boston.

Given ongoing uncertainty around the UK consumer and high-street
backdrop, we believe the return to a greater than 3% LFL despite a tough comp and impact of the hot weather early in the quarter is testament to the strength of the Greggs business.

BE11:24am

And a bit of Canaccord, to fill the space.

BE11:25am

FY18 is a record year for supply-chain investment which is part of a bigger three-year plan. Current activity is focused on new national dough-nut production, internal relocation of pizza production and adapting logistics to cope with the increasingly national production. It is also a big year for IT with the human resources and estate management modules of the new SAP system being installed in the next quarter, with payroll due to follow in early 2019. The higher dual-running costs and the accelerated depreciation are broadly covered by the £6.1m exceptional charge for this year.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Once these projects are complete, it will have the capacity to grow to c.2,500 shops, a 32% increase in shop capacity. Capex is running at c.£90m pa but should revert to maintenance levels from 2021; in addition, we expect Greggs to sell the Twickenham site (c.£20m value) in the next 18 months. It continues to run a net cash balance, so we would expect a resumption of special dividends in the next couple of years.

BE11:31am

The fact that both Apollo and Bain are still in discussions gives
us confidence that the debate around the supposed accounting issues is not a deal breaker. This is the major difference between the first approaches and the extension into the now second phase. Clearly a bid is not guaranteed but if there was an issue with the numbers, logic suggests that Apollo and Bain would have walked away by now.

BE11:32am

The next month will be pivotal for RPC. If there is no bid, the bears will take hold – which we saw yesterday when the stock was down 9% at one point in the morning reflecting nervousness about the outcome – while if there is a bid, a minimum of 950p to 1000p feels to be the tolerance range for shareholders. It is not the ‘right’ price in our view hence our 1230p Target Price but one determined by the turbulence over the last eighteen months.

A. M. @Excel Developer: all true, and yet..
Dec69 - Skeptic 11th hour bartering @BE. A rocket scientist isn't required to work out the reasoning for the adjusted EBIT shows near 11%, but subco's only show 5.4% EBIT margins. Then again, people maybe like to add up differently.
11:33 am
BE11:34am

And Caz.

Dec69 - Skeptic 950-1000p? I'd love to see Peel Hunt's model.
BE11:34am

The participation of two named suitors may augur well for
an eventual offer coming in above the current share price.

BE11:34am

Do Apollo and Bain see a valuation opportunity? RPC’s main international listed peers (Amcor, Aptar, Berry, Pact) trade on an average FY1 EV/EBITDA of 10.3x and an FY1 EV/EBITDA of 9.4x. We estimate that putting RPC on a March 2020 (FY2) EV/EBITDA of 9.4x implies a share price of 1,150p, which is 3% above our September 2019 price target of 1,120p. On our earnings estimates for FY20, a possible offer price of say, 1,000p, would imply an EV/EBITDA multiple in that year of 8.4x, which is more than a 10% discount to the peers.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

And, inevitably, Northern Trust Capital Markets.

A. M. (next thing you know it would no to kaiserschmarren)
BE11:36am

After stating we thought a buy-out was unlikely, we will have to wait up to
another month for clarity on whether RPC remains a public company. Our
thesis on negative underlying profit and FCF growth ought to be more easily tested at 1H19 results in late November – that is if RPC is still listed. We have run various LBO scenarios based on our forecasts and still believe the starting EV/FCFF multiple is already high vs peers and a significant
stumbling block to an LBO. It would need very significant FCF growth to
generate an attractive IRR, which again we think will be difficult as we
believe underlying FCF (and EBIT) growth is negative at RPC. Capex is high by industry standards at more than 6% of sales and is an obvious area to
reduce in order to substantially grow FCF. We wonder how much capex can be cut for a sustained period without negatively impacting profit growth. This is probably a key area of focus for Private Equity we think. Time will tell.

Dec69 - Skeptic @BE it's only on the model on an adjusted basis. Is a worry that the amateurs can spot issues? Whereas Berry/AMcor and even World Wide Packaging (Bain purchased awhile back) are significantly better, and don't need to provision or reverse factor.
Dec69 - Skeptic Alternatively, RPC could acquire another company with little in the way of synergies, a recycle bin company or hazardous waste company.
BE11:38am

Then there's the usual unpicking of RPC's LFL (from continuing operations) and its one-offs. All stuff we've covered a lot in the past, and @Dec69 is recapping to himself over on the right.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

In short, cost savings and synergy gains are less than RPC’s cost inflation YoY in recent years. We need full financial statements to properly judge growth at RPC we believe.

We are not surprised that Mark Wilson has stepped down. The share
price has flatlined over the last 5 years and more recently we have been unclear as to what the Group strategy is going forward. In our view Mark Wilson did a good job in focussing the business but, like many others, we struggle to see where growth will come from. The more recent debacle over the Pref shares and the acceptance of a NED role at Blackrock has not helped confidence either.

Kirkie wayneJ - don't know about now - but they'd found a way to justify not having one a few years ago!
Dec69 - Skeptic Only if one acknowledges the issues. Otherwise it's 'best of success' and buy the dips.
BE11:43am

Aviva "seems to have lost its strategic direction in recent times and as such we believe the change will probably be well received" they say.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

We believe that there are two strong internal candidates - Andy Briggs
(CEO, UK Insurance) and Maurice Tulloch (CEO, International Insurance) both of whom would be very credible although we would understand why some shareholders may feel that a fresh face is required.

wayneJ ....cos the alternative would be a cynical management quietly stripping equity out of the French business before letting the counterpart to the golden ticket policies go bust......something that MFC can't do as it is based in Canada.
BE11:44am

And Barclays.

cheeckychappy I was just counting the number of houses on the market on Rightmove.co.uk in Chelsea above £10 million and it came to at least 20...
BE11:45am

The company argues that this is an amicable split, with Mr Wilson assisting with the planned and orderly transition. However the CEO is leaving with immediate effect, being put on immediate gardening leave, with his bonus being proportioned up until the start of gardening leave, and has lost his unvested LTIP awards, suggesting he is not being made a good leaver. Mr Wilson was also not present at the recent BAML financial conference, and the company cancelled their upcoming CMD a number of weeks ago.

In our view, Mark Wilson has actually done a better job than he has been given credit for. Aviva has grown operating EPS by a 6% CAGR, tangible book value by a 12% CAGR and DPS by a 16% CAGR over the five full years he was CEO (2013 to 2017). While the stock has lagged since his appointment (+22% since January 2012, versus sector (SXIP) +57%, Prudential +85%, Legal & General +71% and FTSE 100 +20%), the company was in a perilous financial position when he joined, with significant internal and external debt leverage, negative cash-flow and too high a dividend. His first action was to cut the dividend, he simplified the business, acquired Friends Life (effectively a non dilutive rights issue which fixed the balance sheet) and sold the foreign businesses / JVs which were not contributing to cash (France JVs, Spanish JVs, Friends Provident International). The first thing the past three Aviva CEO’s have done is cut the dividend, we do not think the next CEO needs to be the fourth. However, Mr Wilson lost the confidence of investors as the restructuring took longer than expected and longer than he indicated (arguably it is only complete now – 2018 the first year of much lower restructuring costs – 2018 restructuring costs £50m versus average of £250m over the past five years). Mr Wilson lost investors confidence with the Friends Life transaction, which in our view was the major piece of the restructuring to fix Aviva’s balance sheet, but many investors believed the balance sheet could be fixed organically. We believe the Friends Life deal was the right thing to do (we upgraded the stock post the deal), but it deviated from managements narrative.

However, with the restructuring seemingly finally behind Aviva, it is the right time for a new CEO to take over. Although a more amicable split would have been desired. Investors will obviously question on whether there was a much bigger disagreement behind the scenes on strategy (material M&A, returning capital to shareholders etc). The company has reiterated its target of delivering operating EPS growth of 5% in 2018, a dividend payout of 55 to 60% by 2020 and is Solvency 2 ratio is above 180% as at September 2018.

The announcement may be a shock to the some but in our view the rationale and timing make sense. Mark has completed a turnaround of the balance sheet and geographic footprint of the business. The share price has been frustrating of late and has largely unrewarded this turnaround. The story going forward is about addressing skepticism on earnings delivery and franchise quality and a new CEO may be better positioned for this. We see the bench strength during the transition period as strong and there are no changes to group targets. We re-iterate our Buy position on one of our top picks in the sector

imp any comment on WPP / Ford?
BE11:54am

The most disturbing aspect of the profit warning on 1 October, to our minds, was the update on productivity. Management reported that there was virtually no improvement in the first half (0.1%) and the full year will fall “significantly below target,” which was to be at the “upper end” of the 2% to 3% range. The cost avoidance target for the current financial year will now be 60% (GBP130m) lower at GBP100m. The group’s track record on productivity has, hitherto, been strong and this slowdown is a significant concern, in our view. The future benefit to be unlocked from the recent pay and pensions deal with the unions was one of the main foundations of our Buy case. Many questions remain unanswered and management’s commitment to provide an update at the H1 results on 15 November and at an investor seminar in 2019 merely prolongs the uncertainty.

BE11:54am

Were it not for the productivity issues, we do not think the group would have had to issue a profit warning.

Dec69 - Skeptic @IMP after 75 years, that's some a/c to lose. Are WPP now at risk of losing some talent?

wayneJ Far me it for me to suggest that there was an off the shelf software package from the late '80s / '90s that, with the pro version, would have done it all for them.
11:55 am
BE11:56am

RMG’s 2019-2020 labour deal sets wages rising, working week falling -
so 2018/19E-2019/20E productivity needs to rise 8-9%. Starting FY19E
so far behind (at 0.1%) means even greater progress is needed in FY20E.
The company also needs to counter and catch-up on the accumulated
buildup of other inflation and falling letter revenues.
• We think lost cost productivity momentum means that in future RMG
will need to work even harder just to catch-up. Inability to hit shortterm
ambitions does not augur well for doing even better than had been
planned to catch-up in future.

BE11:56am

Dividend supported for FY19E-20E: Our base case FCF suggest RMG can
continue to pay DPS and grow DPS 1p a year. FY19/20E DPS is covered
by free cash flow and ND/EBITDA at 1.9 suggests fears (we find) of an
imminent (FY18/19E) DPS cut look unlikely to materialize.

BE11:57am

Mail profit disappointers imply elevated DPS yield requirement: bpost,
CTT and Post NL have a history of profit disappointments. These
shares see investors demand DPS yields higher than regular income
(‘sunset industries’) shares – at greater than 8% DPS yield. However, with UK 10-year government bond yield approx. 1pct pt higher than these peers’
countries, we think RMG shares require an approx. 9% DPS yield for
its operations. So, at 25p DPS, trading supports 270-275p/share with
property value (not in core EPS or DPS yield) increasing that to 315p.
• Underperform, 315p PT as scenario outcome balance swings to risk
downside: On the upside we see a normalized yield leading to 460p (~
+34%) but ~68% downside to 110p possible. 460p needs clear ‘proof’
of productivity growth and full catch-up. 110p is possible if productivity
remains stalled, stamp prices rise at CPI, thus seeing DPS falling to 10p
(at a 90% payout).

BE12:01pm

WPP has previously disclosed the Ford relationship is worth c4% of net sales, making Ford WPP's largest client (P&G and Unilever are c2% of net sales each). In 2017, we estimate based on Ad Age data, creative represented c25% of group revenues. Assuming Ford spend with WPP is in line with clients overall, this would imply Ford creative spend is c1% of WPP group net sales. Given WPP has not lost all of its creative business, we therefore estimate the impact to be between 50-100bps on an annualised basis. If we factor in potential price pressure on Media and PR contract renewals and Ford moving spend in house, then the impact could be larger at c100-200bps in 2019. WPP has yet to release a statement quantifying the impact.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Given changes will not come into effect until 1st November 2018, we think impact on FY18 organic growth will be limited. However, given our current forecast for FY19E organic net sales growth of +1.3%, this news puts growth in FY19 at risk. A 1-2% cut to organic net sales is a c2-4% impact on EPS. Post the loss of Ford, there is also an additional risk that WPP announces a major restructuring of its creative business (-5% in FY17 based on Adage data) to position the division for growth at its strategy day in Dec-18. We also believe the strategy day will need to address how WPP plans to turn around its US business (now negative for the last 6 quarters), creative and DIM (also negative for the last 6 quarters) business units and at what cost.
